title: 105_hr1398
content: The "Parkinson's Research Act of 1997" aims to expand federal investment in Parkinson's disease research and improve coordination among National Institutes of Health research institutes. It also seeks to enhance care and assistance for individuals with Parkinson's and their family caregivers. The Director of NIH will establish a program for Parkinson's disease research and training, coordinating with national research institutes and holding research planning conferences. Additionally, Core Center Grants will be awarded to promote innovation. The Director of NIH will award up to 10 Core Center Grants for multidisciplinary research on Parkinson's disease. Each center funded will be designated as a Morris K. Udall Center for Research on Parkinson's Disease, conducting basic and clinical research and may also offer training programs for scientists and health professionals. The Morris K. Udall Centers for Research on Parkinson's Disease conduct programs for information dissemination to health professionals and the public, establish a nationwide data system, a Disease Information Clearinghouse, and a national education program. The Morris K. Udall Centers for Research on Parkinson's Disease focus on fostering national awareness and care for Parkinson's patients. The program includes stipends for training programs and support for a maximum of five years, extendable upon review. Additionally, the Director of NIH establishes a grant program to support researchers excelling in Parkinson's research. The Morris K. Udall Centers for Research on Parkinson's Disease provide grants for researchers with potential breakthroughs in understanding Parkinson's, with funding authorized for up to 5 years. There is a limitation on the use of funds for research involving human fetal tissue for Parkinson's therapy.
